Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Helping Students Acquire 21st Century Skills Through Immersive Group STEM Simulations
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will automate an experiential simulation learning lab by funding the technical conversion from what is essentially a hardwired product requiring a dedicated lab available to schools within a limited geographic area to a nationally available online product. Additionally, the funding will drive the technological innovation necessary to maintain the immersive, experiential nature of the existing prototype. The project will also allow for research on the underlying assumption of the product: will students be more engaged during content instruction if they are aware that they will be asked to apply their learning in an upcoming simulation? And, if so, will the improved engagement carry over to improved performance on summative assessments? Since the unique nature of the product places it in the middle of the educational technology continuum between digital content and assessment, using current market trends to estimate its sales potential is difficult. However, offering the product online will dramatically decrease its current price point, making the product economically attractive to thousands of teachers and schools across the United States seeking curriculum that engages students who learn best in a team-oriented environment and fosters skill in collaborative, multi-disciplinary problem solving.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the technological innovation that will convert the labor intensive, hardware dependent prototype into an automated online product while maintaining its immersive, engaging qualities. The main objective of the innovation is to create a powerful tool for the classroom teacher that can be implemented in a large lab or on a single computer. A corresponding objective is to determine how effectively the tool engages students in the subject matter and develops real life skills that are in high demand in the 21st century workplace. Teachers will be able to choose from three distinct platforms: Mission Control, a space exploration simulation; Leadership Summit, a global policy making simulation; and Ecosphere, a simulation of areas hidden to the human eye. While being technologically sophisticated, the product also needs to be simple to install and to require minimal training to operate. The product will incorporate multiple controls so that teachers can monitor their students? interactions and manage their progress for optimum effect. Finally, the innovation will also make use of the latest developments in commercially available sound and lighting enhancement products giving teachers control of the timing and level of external sounds and lights.

POR.DRECONTENT:
For this SBIR project, Discovery Simulations LLC proposed to begin development on an experiential simulation platform for the K-12 marketplace. The platform will be a central tool for educators who understand that schools must shift from the 20th-century model of teacher-centered instruction and standardized testing to a 21st-century model of student-centered classrooms and performance-based assessment. Students will capstone classroom instruction by embarking as a group on ?missions? where their subject knowledge and 21st-century skills will be put to the test through practical application. The overall goal of the platform is to directly counteract the following:

  • Student apathy. Helping students find value in what they are learning is one of the most effective ways to improve performance. This project equips teachers with a hands-on application scenarios that allow students to use what they are learning and see its value immediately after learning it. This helps capture student interest and drive greater retention of curricular subject matter.

  • Skill and knowledge gaps. This project is designed to give students experience in critical 21st-century skills that are not being taught as a part of their regular instruction, but are necessary for their future success in the workplace. In addition to providing this essential skills practice, the project will also deliver the means to more regularly assess the students. Most assessments are heavily resisted, or not timely enough to provide actionable insights. The fact that the project will establish a regular pattern of curricular assessment that students enjoy will help teachers recognize and close knowledge and skill gaps more quickly.

  • Marginalization. More and more students are finding themselves in a position where they feel they are not capable of succeeding. For many, the basics of what school requires is not where they excel. This project places students in an abstract situation where they are expected to move around, speak out of turn, and problem solve creatively through this challenge based learning experience - which often come more naturally to those that typically struggle in a traditional classroom setting. If the reach of the program is sufficient, it could change the course of an entire generation of students that would have otherwise given up on themselves.

During Phase I, the following objectives were completed:

  1. Created a working prototype. As proposed, a Phase I prototype was developed that consists of the necessary hardware and software components to run a group simulation. The hardware consists of the needed automated lighting and audio integration components that create the simulation?s setting. The software involves all the needed student interface components (consisting of a baseline of 31 unique interconnected roles that can be filled by students), and the initial library of curriculum-tied simulations (including all needed graphics, animations, audio files, and storylines).

  2. Generated early-adopter user base. Initially, we gathered feedback from two schools that agreed to be early developmental pilots. This helped to establish the guidelines for the teacher tools, student interface, and starting hardware package. Then, after the initial prototype was completed, we endeavored to find 20 schools willing to utilize the program. Due to overwhelmingly positive response to our efforts this initial base of user schools grew to nearly 50 by the close of the Phase I cycle.

  3. Established a teacher-centered development model. A central tenet of this program?s design was to ensure the prototype was given as early as possible to the target end-users. This would help development efforts be focused on the feedback and requests of the end-users. Thus far it has proven to be invaluable in guiding developmental efforts.

  4. Commenced research. The last task of Phase I was to ensure that the program could have measurable impact on student performance to solidify its position as a valuable teaching resource. Teachers are under tremendous pressure to perform, and if we are able to provide a tool that enhances student academic performance while simultaneously addressing the need for 21st-century readiness then the program?s likelihood to succeed is greatly increased. This research will carry well on through the coming years. To start, groups of user/control groups have been created and initial data is being gathered to ensure appropriate measures are being taken to ensure maximum program impact and viability.

Each of these Phase I objectives was successfully completed, and the research with students and educators produced compelling evidence that we can achieve our broader innovation R&D goals.

Through the experiential simulation platform, we aim to help students build skills that will allow them to contribute as individuals and as leaders to the solutions of the significant problems facing our world. We are confident that empowering teachers with timely insights, eliminating the negative personal effects of the educational system, and connecting critical cognitive skills and 21st-century competencies to content knowledge will help to create the problem solvers, critical thinkers, and innovators so vital to the future.
